data.title: Community column: Point Richmond hosts concert by bluegrass favorite Laurie Lewis

data.text:
The next Point Richmond Acoustic Music concert is a bluegrass show featuring Grammy-winning singer and songwriter Laurie Lewis and her band, the Right Hands at 7:30 p.m. April 10.

The show by the Bay Area favorite will be in the historic and intimate space at First United Methodist Church, 201 Martina Ave. in Point Richmond and is expected to sell out.

Along with Lewis, a two-time Female Vocalist of the Year by the International Bluegrass Music Association, the ensemble includes Tom Rozum on mandolin, Patrick Sauber on banjo, fiddler Chad Manning and bassist Max Schwartz.

It will be the third appearance by Lewis at the Point Richmond series.

The opening act will be Bay Area singer/songwriter Richard Brandenburg.

Advance tickets are $20, available online at www.pointacoustic.org, or $25 at the door.

STUDENT JAZZ STANDOUTS: Groups from two local high schools finished first and second in combo category at the Next Generation Jazz Festival, the Monterey Jazz Festival announced.

The Berkeley High School Combo A, directed by Sarah Cline, was selected for the top place at the performance competition held March 27 to 29, which should come as no surprise. BHS has won the combo division 17 times since 1975.

The runner-up in the category was the El Cerrito High School Jazz Quintet directed by Keith Johnson.

The festival featured 88 bands and guests from 11 states and Canada.

GARDEN VARIETY NEWS: Butterfly authority Arthur Shapiro, professor of evolution and ecology at UC Davis, will give a free talk at 11 a.m. April 11 on the first day of the Spring Party at Annie’s Annuals in Richmond.

Shapiro has been monitoring and collecting data on 150 butterfly species for 34 years and tracking population numbers amid changing climate and diminishing habitat.

“Come learn which plants are most likely to attract and sustain butterflies in our area and how to plant a seasonal succession of blooms that serve the different species that appear at different times of year.”

The talk is part of the Spring Party from 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. April 11 and 12 at Annie’s Annuals, 740 Market Ave. in Richmond.

Festivities will include music and belly dancing, free snacks, games, face-painting, prizes and informative talks.

For more details visit www.anniesannuals.com or call 888-266-4370.

The city’s Environmental and Health Initiatives Department will be hosting a free compost giveaway for residents at the event at the former Adams Middle School.

There also will be the Great Tomato Plant Sale, featuring 35 varieties of starts, along with other types of vegetable plants, available for $3 each, along with free advice from Contra Costa Master Gardeners and agriculture group Urban Tilth.

The first program, “Starting a Vegetable Garden,” will cover what grows well in El Cerrito, raised bed and in-ground containers, sun exposure and wind protection, and soil.

Programs, hosted by the El Cerrito Community Garden Network and El Cerrito Library, will be held at 2 p.m. on May 23 (Starting Plants from Seeds), June 27 (Organic gardening principles), July 25 (Soil Building), Sept. 26 (Harvesting and Cooking), Oct. 24 (Winter Garden and Seed Saving), and Nov. 28 (Fruit Trees and Bushes).

Each program will start with a 30-minute presentation at the library, 6510 Stockton Ave., followed by a hands-on project at the Community Demonstration Garden a short walk away at Fairmont Park near the Ohlone Greenway.

The series is free, but registration is required. Go to and click on the calendar link for the program you want.

WEST COUNTY NOTES: An update and film presentation on the Berkeley Tuolomne Camp and its destruction in the 2013 Rim Fire will be held at 7 p.m. April 14 at Freight and Salvage Coffeehouse, 2020 Addison St. in Berkeley.

The program hosted by Friends of Berkeley Tuolomne Camp will include footage rescued from the camp that shows how it looked in 1948, footage of what it looks like today, along with “an update on the camp’s future, and talks on how you can be involved in the future of the Stanislaus Forest.”

The group warns that “The presentation includes video of The Rim Fire up close — we hear and see the fire in amazing footage. This event may not be good for small children.”

For tickets and details visit .

A National Park Service presentation on planned signage “to recognize San Pablo Avenue’s place along the Juan Bautista de Anza National Historic Trail” will be held from 5 to 7 p.m. April 30 in the Hillside Conference Room at El Cerrito City Hall, 10890 San Pablo Ave.

The signage project is being done in partnership with the city and the El Cerrito Historical Society with installation planned for this August. Details: .
